This reporting the fatal charges F. Wagner
July 49, 1863 led by the Fiffourth Massachusetts REGIMENT
in which William H. Carney the flag bearer, distinguished him
self.


Said the officer further: e received wound IN the
thigh upon He planted the flag the para
pet lay other SLOPE that he might get as much shell
possible. there he remained for half an hour till the
End brigade the coors flying until the second
conflict was retired he followed creeping
on knee, still holding up the flag"


that Sergeant Carney came from the Held having
held the emblem the walls Of Fort Wagner during
the sangnay conflict the brigdes and having received
two very wounds the thigh and one IN the head
st he refused up until he found Off
of his regiment.


When he entered the hospital where his wounded comrades
we're being brought h they cheered him and the color Though
nearly exhausted with blood he sad Boys the old flag
never touched the ground :"

Views, pRevlFws
MD Reviews


Edward Banks

Spring is the time for birds,
bees, kites, umbrellas, cotton
dresses, house cleaning and kerr
ker-choo-oo, allergy attacks.


Some poets have written Of the
beauties of the flora and fauna
which comes to life in the second
quarter Of the year.


Pictures Of wee chicks, flop
cared rabbits, waddling geese,
slick skinned puppies and wiggly
fish conjure up poems and rhymes
of praise.


Fields of vermillion roses,
violet hued irises, yellow daffo-
dis and alabaster carnations
cause songwriters many happy
moments.


The familiar shouts Of children
trailing after kites or the NUT
terings Of band Of boys kneel-
ing before a marble circle means
spring Is here.


Other persons have their own
manner Of learning the season Is
here. Some merely turn the cal
endar. Some see 1t in the morning
dew. Some hear the tunes Of
spring over the radio or tele-
vision.


Farmers know by the bleats Of
lambs or the birth Of a calf or
colt.


Auto racers watch tryouts as
cars and drivers hope to enter
the classic 500 mile Indianapolis
race.


Baseball lovers follow the trips
of big league teams and watch
performances Of seas oned and
rockies. Hoping for new records
to be broken, they sift the facts
and predict the Yankees can or
can not be beaten.


Far In the distance another
sign Of spring can be seen. If
you live near a playground the
sounds Of springtime echo more
often. The sounds become louder
as the summer begins Its jour
ney from three short months as
the calendar goes.


All of the sights and sounds
of spring reach a zenith In the
Valley of the Sun, especially on
the southside. At this time OF
year the Japanese flower gardens
are In bloom and as the beautiful
posies bank the ground the
smell watts through the desert
air.


| 90 ker-ker-choo-oo and |
know darn we'll It's just
s-p-r-i-n-g. Againl

This week Malcolm X, the former second
commander of the Black Mus Inns, announced
he mus planning third party composed of all
Negroes to min political power in the United
States.


He urged Negroes to join his black ma
ti0naliSt party and take UP not only ballots
but arms. His TRADES cause many persons
to sO0ndeY If Malcolm X is ia cling reality or
is he man hUirag in dream World.


Just how far could Negroes min anything
at the polls as a third party? H0w could they
control any legis lathe district? How could
they elect candidates on a strictly racial
basis?


Malcolm X also said that Negroes should
take up arms and fight for their freedoms.
Has he forgotten that though Negroes COM
prise the largest single minority GROUP in
the United States-they are still minority.


While rioting flared again in Florida and
other blaces--the threats of violence haze
more onainous sound. The death of Negro
mother Walking home in Florida is not an
incident to be proud OF.


All hving and learning in our democracy
wiH haze been of little vah4e If the blacks
and whites must resort to the steel and buL-
lets.
